newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Export agent understands Russia PGM decree signed.
newsitem.headline: Export agent understands Russia PGM decree signed.

text.p: Russia's platinum group metals (PGM) export agent, Almazjuvelirexport, said on Wednesday that it believed a long-delayed Russian government decree outlining 1997 PGM exports had been signed.
"The decree has already been signed by the government," deputy director of the agency told Reuters.
"It happened in the last few days, although we have not yet received a copy of the decree," he said, adding that he could not therefore fully confirm that the decree had been signed.
Sergei Gorny also said that the signing of the decree should allow talks between Russia and Japan over 1997 deliveries of PGMs to start soon.
"I don't think it will be long (before talks with Japan resume)," Gorny said.
"I don't want to put a date on it, because you know how markets move on that kind of news. But if the decree is signed then the normal process will start quickly enough."

Talks between Japan, the world's biggest palladium consumer, and Russia, the world's biggest palladium producer, have been held up by Moscow's failure to pass a decree setting out PGM export quotas this year.
Contract talks are usually held in December for deliveries to begin in the next calendar year. Palladium prices have soared in reaction to the delays.
Gorny said that the delays were the result of government and cabinet changes earlier in the year, and of protracted wrangling over the 1997 federal budget.
He said it was unlikely export delays were connected with a struggle for control over Russia's secretive precious metals and stones market.
"Traditionally Almaz has been the export agent for platinum and palladium for the government," Gorny said. "If there had been talks to the contrary, then presumably we would have known about them."
Some Japanese traders had said it appeared that Russia's central bank was trying to win a slice of the PGM export business, holding talks with Japanese trade houses on the matter last month.
Central bank, Finance Ministry, and now Almazjuvelirexport officials have all said they were unaware of the talks.
Gorny said that he was not aware of 1997 PGM quota volumes.
"I simply do not know. The size of the quotas are secret."
